LEAD: The Indian Government grounded all 14 Airbus A320 aircraft flown by its domestic carrier today after the crash of an Airbus plane last week that killed 97.
The Indian Government grounded all 14 Airbus A320 aircraft flown by its domestic carrier today after the crash of an Airbus plane last week that killed 97.

The decision was made after a meeting of top officials of Indian Airlines, the Government-run carrier, and the Civil Aviation Ministry, who appointed a committee to investigate the airline's ability to operate the sophisticated aircraft.
Indian Airlines' chairman, R. Prasad, resigned last week, accepting ''moral responsibility'' for the crash.

The grounding of the aircraft is expected to disrupt the schedule of Indian Airlines, which carries about 11,000 passengers a day with a fleet that also includes Boeing 737's. The airline has been criticized frequently for delays and inefficient service.

In another incident involving one of the airline's A320's, a flight from the southern city of Madras on Saturday returned only 20 minutes after takeoff when passengers complained of breathing difficulties.
The crash occurred on Wednesday as the plane, with 146 on board, came down short of the runway at the airport of the southern city of Bangalore.
The Press Trust of India reported that the Government had set up a court of inquiry led by a high court judge to investigate the crash.

The decision to buy 31 of the wide-bodied aircraft for about $1.2 billion - the rest of the planes have not been delivered - was made under the administration of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, who was voted out of office last year.
There has been widespread criticism of the deal, much of it focusing on the apparent unpreparedness of the airline and ground installations in maintaining the aircraft.
In November, airline maintenance engineers organized a protest seeking more training in Toulouse, France, at the headquarters of Airbus Industrie, the European consortium that manufactures the plane.
